>So said Andrew McDonagh on 2003-07-24 --------------------
>
>I understan=
d your reasoning, but from a personal point of view, I'd prefer
>to see the=
 one physical test fail during one of the logical tests.  

No-one can argu=
e with personal preference. I just wouldn't do it that way. If I have 10 te=
sts, I want JUnit to say "10 runs". I find no compelling reason to do other=
wise. If you have one, then by all means, use it.

>I see
>the logical test=
s as just a series of asserts within the same testcase, but
>refactored to =
remove 'some' duplication.
>
>eg.
>
>public void testRangeValues() {
>     =
 assertEquals(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
>      assertEquals(Inte=
ger.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
>      assertEquals(new Integer(0), new In=
teger(0));
>}
>
>becomes...
>
>public void testRangeValues() {
>      testT=
woIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
>      testTwoIntegers(Inte=
ger.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
>      testTwoIntegers(new Integer(0), new=
 Integer(0));
>}

This doesn't remove duplication; it only reveals intent. =
My suggestion removes the duplication (as would a simple loop in this case)=
. It's an important distinction.

>Note: This is a simplistic example...obv=
iously we'd be doing more than
>testing two integers - to answer the origin=
al question.

I don't suppose it matters what the tests actually do for the=
 purposes of this conversation; just that we want to run the same test for =
n sets of data.

Take care.
